result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (3rd) and Operating w/ PAC (3rd). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (3rd) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (3rd) was dismissed by the court.

  • Luke James Straszewski was found guilty of OWI (3rd), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Attorney Thomas J. Marola in court, defendant Luke James Straszewski not in court, in custody.  Jeffrey James Altenburg appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Deputy Court Clerk ssm.  ENTRY MADE WITHOUT COURT FILE.  Case calendared at the request of parties.  Statements made as to the condition time ordered.  Court orders the judgment of conviction corrected as follows:

*  As a condition of probation, the defendant is ordered to served 60 days in the House of Correction CONCURRENT to any other condition time; huber for school and treatment; NO ELECTRONIC MONITORING.

Done w/o file.  
No JOC previously printed. Correction per Request and Order signed on 9/22/2015 showing on JOC.

The following clerical error was made in the judgment of conviction:
As a condition of probation the defendant was sentenced to serve 10 days in the House of Correction.

CORRECTION:
As a condition of probation the defendant was sentenced to serve 50 days in the House of Correction.
records.descr: Request and Order to Correct Clerical Error in JOC

records.addlTxt: Associated with Charge #1

Defendant Luke James Straszewski in court with attorney Thomas J. Marola.  Joy Hammond appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Deputy Court Clerk ssm.

AS TO COUNT 2:  Pursuant to plea negotiations and on motion of the State, Court ordered count dismissed.

AS TO COUNT 3:  Pursuant to plea negotiations and on motion of the State, Court ordered count dismissed and read-in.

AS TO COUNT 1:  Defendant changes his plea to GUILTY.  Defendant examined as to his plea, advised of his Constitutional rights and the maximum penalty.   Defendant advised that if not a United States Citizen, deportation is possible.  Court found that defendant knowingly, voluntarily and intelligently waived his rights.  Guilty Plea Questionnaire/Waiver of Rights and Addendum received and filed.  Parties stipulate to the complaint as a factual basis to sustain defendant's plea.  Court found defendant guilty and ordered a Judgment of Conviction be entered on the record.  Sentencing proceeded.  Statements by the State, defense and defendant.  Defendant sentenced to serve 8 MONTHS in the House of Correction CONSECUTIVE to case 14CT002520.  Court STAYED the sentence and placed defendant on Probation with the State of Wisconsin, Department of Corrections for a period of 24 MONTHS.
Conditions: 
*  Pay a fine in the amount of $600.00 plus all costs and surcharges or, if not paid, convert to a civil judgment;
*  AODA assessment/treatment deemed appropriate; order signed and filed;
*  Serve 10 days in the House of Correction.

Court ordered the defendant's driving privileges revoked for 24 months.
Court ordered any vehicle owned/operated by the defendant to be equipped with the Ignition Interlock Device for 24 months and pay the IID surcharge.

Court ordered case transferred to Judge Ashley, Branch 33 for review hearing.
  Review hearing scheduled for November 9, 2015 at 08:30 am.
